dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Have you ever heard of harmony?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, so what do you think harmony is?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think basically it's like, one person has the lower voice and then like, girl usually has the higher voice and then they blend it together.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: I like it. That's absolutely correct.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Harmony is about injecting melody with emotion so that ultimately, you leave home and you return home and you've learned something along the way.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So a nice place to start is with the idea of a triad. A triad is a three-part harmony, basically. (keyboard harmonic tone) So that's a triad. So this triad's called C major.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So have you ever heard of this idea of like, major chords and minor chords?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So this is C major, yeah? (keyboard music) And then this is C minor. So the feelings are different, right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, feels like dark and spooky.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [Jacob] Yeah, this one's dark and spooky.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And how does this one make you feel though?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So in Amazing Grace, you start with F. You know, if I go (melodic humming) ♪ How sweet the sound ♪ (scat singing) (laughs) Where am I right now? I don't know where I am. (scat singing) And my job is to get back home, but to make this chord make sense.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So I might go (hums Amazing Grace)

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh man, that sounded really good.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: My job as a harmonizer is to find that narrative and make it make sense.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: 'Cause I didn't think that that would work together.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Because there were two two completely different sounds, but then, like, it just made it happen and it just was like, pow!
